dt: {bc}a metallic vessel usually used for boiling liquids
{bc}a steep-sided hollow without surface drainage especially in a deposit of glacial drift
{bc}a usually large group of raptors (such as hawks or vultures) circling high in the sky on an updraft of warm air

dt.t: … more than 500 birds have been seen riding the same spiraling thermal air current, or {ldquo}{wi}kettle{/wi},{rdquo} as they are known to hawk-watchers.

et: Middle English {it}ketel{/it}, from Old Norse {it}ketill{/it} (akin to Old English {it}cietel{/it} kettle), both from a prehistoric Germanic word borrowed from Latin {it}catillus{/it}, diminutive of {it}catinus{/it} bowl
shortdef: a metallic vessel usually used for boiling liquids; especially : teakettle

dt: {bc}to corral or contain (people) in large numbers by surrounding and forcing into an enclosed area

dt.t: Police officers stood in a line in front of them but protesters seemed to think they'd be allowed through. They were not. Instead, they were {wi}kettled{/wi} with orange nets, and arrested.

utxt.t: In London, over 30 students were arrested as part of an occupation at Senate House, which included police brutality and {wi}kettling{/wi}.

shortdef: to corral or contain (people) in large numbers by surrounding and forcing into an enclosed area

dt: {bc}a type of potato chip made so as to be thicker and crunchier than the typical potato chip

shortdef: a type of potato chip made so as to be thicker and crunchier than the typical potato chip

dt: {bc}something to be considered or dealt with {bc}{sx|matter||}

shortdef: a bad state of affairs : mess
something to be considered or dealt with : matter
